{{LRA}}
The '''Juba talks''' were a series of negotiations between the government of [[Uganda]] and the [[Lord's Resistance Army]] rebel group over the terms of a ceasefire and possible peace agreement. The talks, held in [[Juba, Sudan|Juba]], the capital of autonomous [[Southern Sudan]], began in July 2006 and were mediated by [[Riek Machar]], the Vice President of Southern Sudan. The talks, which had resulted in a ceasefire by September 2006, were described as the best chance ever for a negotiated settlement to the 20-year-old war.<ref name=BBC_deadline>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4790049.stm Uganda hopeful about rebel talks], BBC News, 14 August 2006</ref> However, LRA leader [[Joseph Kony]] refused to sign the peace agreement in April 2008. Two months later, the LRA carried out an attack on a Southern Sudanese town, prompting the Government of Southern Sudan to officially withdraw from their mediation role.
==Preparations== A delegation from the LRA arrived in [[Juba, Sudan]] on 8 June 2006 to prepare for talks with the Ugandan government, to be mediated by the [[Southern Sudan autonomous region (2005–2011)|Government of Southern Sudan]] <ref name="juba_8_june">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5060666.stm LRA rebels arrive for Sudan talks], BBC News, 8 June 2006</ref> and by the [[Community of Sant'Egidio]].<ref name="Sant'Egidio">{{it icon}}[http://santegidio.de/news/rassegna/2006/0820_004061_IT.htm "Guerra in Nord Uganda: la fine è a portata di mano"], [[Avvenire]], August 20, 2006</ref> These talks were agreed to after Kony released a video in May in which he denied committing atrocities and seemed to call for an end to hostilities, in response to an announcement by Museveni that he would guarantee the safety of Kony if peace was agreed to by July. Museveni had pledged to grant Kony total amnesty if he gave up "[[terrorism]]". Uganda's security minister [[Amama Mbabazi]] urged the [[International Criminal Court]] to drop the indictments issued in 2005 against leaders of the LRA, but LRA legal adviser [[Krispus Ayena Odongo]] rejected the offer, saying that accepting amnesty "presupposes surrender" and would mean the LRA was no longer available for discussions.<ref name="amnesty_rejection">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5157220.stm Uganda LRA rebels reject amnesty], [[BBC News]], 7 July 2006</ref><ref name="drop_charges">[http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_1966651,00.html ICC urged to drop LRA charges] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229135255/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_1966651,00.html |date=2008-02-29 }}, [[BBC News]], 12 July 2006</ref> Several organizations, including the ICC<ref name="amnesty_offer">[http://allafrica.com/stories/200607060715.html Museveni Amnesty to Kony Illegal - ICC], AllAfrica (The Monitor), 6 July 2006</ref> and the [[International Bar Association]]'s Human Rights Institute<ref name="IBA_rejects_amnesty">[http://www.legalbrief.co.za/filemgmt/visit.php?lid=401 IBA says Ugandan Government must meet obligations under the Rome Statute], IBA News Release, 13 July 2006</ref> insisted that LRA leaders must be arrested in accordance with the [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court|Rome Statute]].
[[Joseph Kony]] gave his first interview to the press after 20 years of carrying out the conflict in late June 2006. He denied that the LRA had carried out any atrocities and blamed President Museveni for oppressing the Acholi.<ref name="kony_speaks">Sam Farmar, [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/newsnight/5124762.stm Uganda rebel leader breaks silence], BBC [[Newsnight]], 28 June 2006</ref> Regardless, in late June 2006, the Government of Southern Sudan formally invited Uganda to attend peace talks.<ref name="sudan_invitation">[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=54279 UGANDA: Gov't to send team to Sudan over proposed LRA talks], IRIN, 28 June 2006</ref>
==Initial negotiations== On 14 July 2006 talks began in Juba between delegations from the LRA and Uganda, with the Vice-president of Southern Sudan [[Riek Machar]] as the chief mediator. The leader of the Ugandan delegation, Internal Affairs Minister [[Ruhakana Rugunda]] stated that his priority was to obtain a quick ceasefire.<ref name="Rugunda_comment">[http://allafrica.com/stories/200607140756.html Ceasefire First On Kony Agenda], AllAfrica (The Monitor), 15 July 2006</ref> The LRA delegation, led by [[Martin Ojul]], said that LRA's acceptance of the peace talks should not be interpreted that LRA can no longer fight, but stressed that a negotiated settlement is the best way to end the conflict.<ref name="Ojul_speech">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070401151418/http://www.sundayvision.co.ug/detail.php?mainNewsCategoryId=7&newsCategoryId=132&newsId=509505 Opening speech of LRA delegation at Juba talks], Sunday Vision, 15 July 2006</ref>
The initial delegation was criticized as largely consisting of expatriate Acholi, rather than members of the fighting force. However, after many delays [[Vincent Otti]] arrived for meetings on the 29th,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5227526.stm Key Uganda rebel 'attends talks'], BBC News, 29 July 2006</ref> followed the next day by Kony's 14-year-old son [[Salim Saleh Kony]] (sharing a name with brother of President Museveni, [[Salim Saleh]]).<ref name="BBC meet">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5231042.stm Uganda officials 'meet LRA chief'], BBC News, 30 July 2006</ref> Kony himself met with local religious and political leaders from northern Uganda and southern Sudan on the following day.<ref name="BBC meet"/> On 2 August, Kony held his first ever press conference in which he demanded a ceasefire before LRA-government negotiations resumed on the 7th and denied ever abducting children. Some media sources noted that, of the approximately 80 LRA fighters surrounding the press venue, several appeared to be in their early teens.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=54938 UGANDA: Government, rebels to resume talks in Sudan], IRIN, 2 August 2006</ref><ref>[http://www.rocketboom.com/vlog/archives/2006/08/rb_06_aug_16.html Video footage of peace talks in Juba, plus snippet of Kony press conference] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017135801/http://www.rocketboom.com/vlog/archives/2006/08/rb_06_aug_16.html |date=2006-10-17 }}, video and commentary by Ruud Elmendorp presented on [[Rocketboom]], 16 August 2006</ref>
The broader context of the talks remained confused. The government of Southern Sudan views the talks as a means of ridding itself of a foreign army that is complicating their delicate relationship with the [[Khartoum]] government. The request by the Ugandan Government for ICC to suspend war crimes indictments against leaders of the LRA, condemned by international human rights groups but largely supported by leaders and civilians within northern Uganda, led some political analysts to see Ugandan Government's request as a ploy to gain local support. The comment of a George Olara, an [[Internally displaced person|IDP]] living in a camp in [[Pader District|Pader]], was fairly typical: "He [Kony] should not be taken to [[The Hague]]. Let him come back and live with the community because this is how reconciliation will be achieved. ... [[Peace]] will come if the talks succeed, but there is the potential that they may also fail like they have done before".<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=54920 UGANDA: Locals want rebel leader forgiven], IRIN, 1 August 2006</ref>
==Ceasefire== [[Image:Scharq al-Istiwa'iya.PNG|thumb|left|[[Owiny Ki-Bul]] is in [[East Equatoria]] (in red) bordering [[Uganda]] to the south, [[Kenya]] to the southeast and [[Ethiopia]] to the east.]]
On 4 August 2006, Vincent Otti declared a unilateral ceasefire and asked the Ugandan government to reciprocate. Ugandan Internal Affairs Minister [[Ruhakana Rugunda]] stated that they were waiting to see the effect on the ground.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5243038.stm LRA leaders declare ceasefire], BBC, 4 August 2006</ref> ICC indictee Raska Lukwiya was killed in battle on 12 August 2006; the LRA asked for three days of mourning though a spokesman said that talks would continue.<ref name=BBC_deadline/> Ugandan President Museveni set a 12 September 2006 deadline to finalize a peace deal.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5264742.stm Uganda resumes talks with rebels] ''BBC News'' 18 August 2006</ref> The government and LRA signed a truce on 26 August 2006. Under the terms of the agreement, LRA forces were required to leave Uganda and gather in two assembly areas, where the Ugandan government promised they would not attack and the government of Southern Sudan guaranteed their safety. Once this is accomplished, talks on a comprehensive peace agreement would begin.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5288776.stm Uganda and LRA rebels sign truce], BBC News, 26 August 2006</ref> Although a final agreement was not reached by the 12 August deadline, LRA rebels began gathering in the assembly areas and the government delegation stated that they would not hold to the deadline. Machar stated that several hundred rebels, including Otti, had gathered either at [[Ri-Kwangba]] in [[West Equatoria]] or [[Owiny Ki-Bul]] in [[East Equatoria]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/5337888.stm Uganda drops peace talks deadline], BBC, 12 September 2006</ref>
[[Image:Kitgum IDP camp from the air, Uganda.jpg|thumb|Huts in the [[Kitgum]] IDP camp are tightly packed together]]
The government also began a process of creating "satellite camps" to decongest the main IDP camps. In Pader, 28 satellite sites were occupied out of 48 identified as of late September 2006, while the numbers in [[Kitgum]] were 21 of 36. IDPs farther south in [[Teso sub-region|Teso]] and [[Lango sub-region|Lango]] were being encouraged to return home directly. However, talks continued to be delayed. On 23 September, the LRA delegation threatened to walk out of the negotiations, claiming that the UPDF had attacked their forces at Owiny Ki-Bul and demanding that composition of the government delegation be changed and that the ICC warrants be voided before any agreement. Uganda denied the accusation of attacks. Both delegations met with mediator Riek Machar on 25 September 2006, but not with each other.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55722 UGANDA: Most rebels have left northern Uganda for Sudan - army], IRIN, 26 September 2006</ref>
===Attacks=== The negotiations were paused in early October while a Cessation of Hostilities monitoring team was sent to Owiny Ki-Bul. The team found that no attack had taken place, but that the LRA had simply moved away from the designated site. The team recommended that the LRA rebels regroup at Owiny Ki-Bul, while stating that the LRA had not honored the agreement and was using hostile propaganda, that the UPDF was located close to the assembly points and that the mediators had failed to provide armed guards for the assembled rebels. On 11 October 2006, the LRA proposed that Uganda adopt a [[federalism|federalist]] structure, prompting criticism from the government spokesperson.<ref>[http://irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55906 UGANDA: Rebels propose federalist solution at Juba talks], [[IRIN]], 11 October 2006</ref>
On 20 October 2006, Ugandan President [[Yoweri Museveni]] traveled to Juba to meet the LRA negotiators face-to-face for the first time in an attempt to revive the talks, described as "stalled" by ''[[BBC News]]'' and "faltering" by ''[[The Monitor (Uganda)|The Monitor]]'' newspaper. A Uganda government source reported that the president spoke angrily and rebuked the LRA team several times, before later referring to the LRA as "unserious" in a subsequent address to South Sudan government officials. A pall had been thrown over the talks by the murder of several dozen civilians, including the shooting of women and children in the head, near Juba during the two previous days. The attacks were carried out by an as-yet unnamed group, but some suspected that the LRA was responsible for the mayhem.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6072994.stm "LRA rebels meet Uganda's Museveni"], BBC News, 21 October 2006; [http://irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=56019 "SUDAN: Armed group kills 42 civilians"], ''IRIN'', 20 October 2006; and [http://www.monitor.co.ug/sunday/news/news10227.php "Museveni meets LRA face to face"]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[The Monitor (Uganda)|The Sunday Monitor]]'', 21 October 2006</ref>
After a week-long impasse, the LRA and government signed a second truce on 1 November 2006 that mandated the monitoring team until 1 December. The previous agreement had technically expired in September. As part of the agreement, the army was to withdraw from Owiny Ki-Bul, past a 30-km (18-mi) buffer zone. The LRA was given a week to regroup at Owiny Ki-Bul, and four weeks to gather at Ri-Kwangba. Both Kony and Otti refused to enter the camps, citing fear of arrest on the ICC warrants. The agreement further stated that food would not be provided to LRA units outside the assembly points except in "exceptional circumstances".<ref>[http://irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=56146 "UGANDA: Revised gov't-LRA ceasefire deal signed"], ''IRIN'', 1 November 2006</ref>
In one of the most significant moments for the LRA during the talks, [[United Nations]] [[Undersecretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator]] [[Jan Egeland]] met with Kony and Otti in the hopes of pushing the talks forward on 12 November 2006. Egeland had previously stated that he would meet with Kony only if the LRA released abducted children and wounded members, but Kony denied that anyone in the LRA was either wounded or held against their will.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6139554.stm "UN envoy sees Uganda rebel chief"], ''BBC News, 12 November 2006</ref>
The LRA declared that it was withdrawing from the talks on November 30, stating that UPDF had killed three of its fighters. The deadline for the LRA fighters to finish gathering at the assembly points was 1 December.<ref>[http://irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=56580 "UGANDA: Talks hit fresh snag amid rebel protest"], ''IRIN'', 30 November 2006</ref> Uganda denied the charge. Also, outgoing [[United Nations Secretary-General]] [[Kofi Annan]] appointed [[Joaquim Chissano]], former president of [[Mozambique]], to be the UN envoy to the conflict.<ref>[http://irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=56623 "UGANDA: Museveni optimistic peace will prevail"], ''IRIN'', 5 December 2006</ref> The truce was further extended for two more months on 18 December.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6190283.stm "Ugandan LRA rebel truce extended"], ''BBC News'', 18 December 2006.</ref>
On 12 January 2007 Ojul stated that recent comments made by al-Bashir and Kiir clearly signified that the LRA was not welcome any longer in Sudan, and that further talks should occur in [[Kenya]] instead.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6255369.stm "Rebels snub Ugandan peace talks"], BBC News, 12 January 2007</ref><ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200701200030.html "Uganda: LRA Quit Juba Talks, Govt Rejects Rebels' Demands"], allAfrica.com, 21 January 2007.</ref> On 14 March 2007 the LRA stated it would once again return to the Juba talks.<ref>http://allafrica.com/stories/200703140450.html</ref> After [[South Africa]], [[Kenya]] and [[Mozambique]] agreed to join the peace talks (a demand the LRA had made before it would return to Juba), the next round of talks was held from 13 April to 14 April 2007.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200704021629.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: S. Africa, Kenya Join Juba Peace Talks (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In this round, the ceasefire was extended until 30 June 2007, and [[Ri Kwangba]] was the agreed upon assembly point. The next round of talks was set for 25 April 2007.<ref>[http://www.monitor.co.ug/sunday/news/news041510.php "Govt, LRA talks underway"]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Sunday Monitor]], 15–21 April 2007</ref>
==Resumption== Following this suspension in the peace talks, the [[Juba Initiative Project]] enabled the resumption of the talks in May 2007, thanks to the efforts of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for LRA-affected areas [[Joaquim Chissano]]. The talks were again mediated by the Government of [[Southern Sudan]], but with the support of the [[United Nations]] and logistic facilitation from the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), under the leadership of her local head [[Eliane Duthoit]].<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=72489 "SUDAN-UGANDA: LRA talks, pencils and helicopters"], ''IRIN'', 31 May 2007</ref>
On 29 June 2007, the sides agreed to the principles of how justice and reconciliation will be handled, the third of the five-point agenda. The LRA and government agreed that both formal justice procedures and the traditional [[Mato Oput]] ceremony of reconciliation would play a role. Government delegation spokesperson Barigye Ba-Hoku stated that they would attempt to convince the ICC that this would address their concerns about impunity and that arrests under ICC auspices would not be necessary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=73010 |title=UGANDA: LRA talks reach agreement on accountability |publisher=Irinnews.org |date=2007-06-30 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> In November 2007, an LRA delegation led by [[Martin Ojul]] journeyed to Kampala to restate their commitment to a peaceful resolution of the conflict. Ojul later led the delegation on a tour of northern Uganda to meet victims of the insurgency and ask their forgiveness. However, reports surfaced that LRA deputy commander Otti had been executed on or around 8 October 2007 over an internal power struggle with Kony.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7082437.stm "Ugandan rebel deputy feared dead"] ''BBC News'', 7 November 2007</ref>
On 20 December 2007 the government set an ultimatum for the peace talks to conclude by 31 January 2008, threatening that a new military offensive otherwise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7153670.stm |title=Africa | Uganda LRA rebels given ultimatum |publisher=BBC News |date=2007-12-20 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> The death of [[Vincent Otti]], confirmed in mid-January 2008, was reported to threaten the success of the talks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7208562.stm |title=Africa | Rebel death may hurt Uganda talks |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-01-25 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> Talks resumed on 30 January 2008, and the ceasefire was extended until 29 February 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hklZqacPJl3eL-r2SYEqLPFs-7lQ |title=AFP: Ugandan government, rebels extend ceasefire |publisher=Afp.google.com |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2012-06-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612134732/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hklZqacPJl3eL-r2SYEqLPFs-7lQ |archive-date=2008-06-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The [[European Union]] and the [[United States]] joined the negotiations, increasing the number of observers to eight.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200801300995.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: U.S., EU Join Juba Peace Talks (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A breakthrough in negotiations was reached on 3 February 2008 regarding accountability and reconciliation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article25807 |title=Uganda and LRA agree on accountability mechanisms |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> A deal was signed on 19 February 2008 which decided that the war crimes would be tried in a special section of the [[High Court of Uganda]], thus bypassing the [[International Criminal Court]] and also removing one of the last obstacles to a final peace deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7252774.stm |title=Africa | Ugandans reach war crimes accord |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-02-19 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> On 22 February 2008, the rebels walked out of the talks again after being denied senior government posts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/02/22/africa/AF-GEN-Uganda-Rebels.php |title=Ugandan rebels, government sign deal |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date=2009-03-29 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> However, shortly thereafter they signed another breakthrough agreement according to which they "would be considered for government and army posts", but not automatically appointed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7259636.stm |title=Africa | New breakthrough in Uganda talks |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-02-22 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> A permanent ceasefire to come into effect 24 hours after the signing a comprehensive peace treaty (expected by 29 February 2008) was agreed upon on 23 February 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7260798.stm |title=Africa | Uganda and LRA agree to ceasefire |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-02-23 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article26110 |title=Uganda, rebel LRA signs permanent ceasefire agreement in Juba |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref>
More problems appeared on 28 February 2008: The rebels demand a retraction of the ICC indictments, but the Ugandan government only wants to ask the UN to do that after the rebels have demobilised.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7268529.stm |title=Africa | Uganda rejects key peace demand |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-02-28 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> An accord on Disarmament, Demobilisation and Reintegration was signed late on 29 February 2008, leaving the signing of the peace treaty itself as the last missing action.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tolerance.ca/Article.aspx?ID=9488&L=en |title=Uganda, rebels sign disarmament accord: government |publisher=Tolerance.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The truce was extended until 28 March 2008,<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200803020040.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: LRA Truce Extended to March 28 (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and the final peace talks will continue on 12 March 2008.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Top_News/2008/03/03/uganda_extends_truce_with_lra/3603/ |title=Uganda extends truce with LRA - UPI.com<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2008-03-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314202442/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/Top_News/2008/03/03/uganda_extends_truce_with_lra/3603/ |archive-date=2008-03-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The ICC prosecutor-general [[Luis Moreno-Ocampo]] on 5 March 2008 rejected demands by the rebels for a meeting, stating that "arrest warrants issued by the court... remain in effect and have to be executed".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7277577.stm |title=Africa | ICC rejects Uganda rebel overture |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-03-05 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> it was reported that rebel leader Kony would nonetheless come out of the bush to sign the peace agreement on 28 March 2008, with the implicit agreement that he will not be apprehended and transferred to the ICC while out in the open; such an action was also thought to likely see a remobilisation of his rebel army. Furthermore, it was suggested that Uganda should lobby at the [[United Nations Security Council]] to suspend the ICC indictments for a year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7279394.stm |title=Africa | Ugandan rebels 'will sign deal' |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-03-05 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref>
On 12 March 2008, as final talks were set to continue, the ICC inquired as to the precise definition of the powers of the proposed intra-Ugandan war crimes court section, in a move seen as softening the indictments on the LRA rebels.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The final signing of the peace deal was delayed on 26 March 2008 from 28 March 2008 to 3 April 2008; while the ceasefire was not formally extended with this deadline, both parties were expected to continue adhering to it.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200803260004.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: LRA Rebels Sign Peace on April 3 (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The signing was then further delayed to 5 April 2008.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200803280320.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: Govt, LRA Sign Second Agreement (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was later announced that Kony would sign the deal in the bush two days before that.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article26540 |title=LRA’s Kony to sign peace deal in bush - South Sudan |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> However, this was postponed to 10 April 2008; reportedly, Kony was suffering from [[diarrhoea]].<ref>[http://politics.nationmedia.com/inner.asp?sid=1723 Mugabe's party expects to fight] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410081448/http://politics.nationmedia.com/inner.asp?sid=1723 |date=April 10, 2008 }}</ref>
The ICC inquired as to the precise nature of the special courts in Uganda.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article26541 |title=ICC inquires into establishment of Special Courts for LRA |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> Kony delayed the signing of the final treaty further on 10 April 2008, reportedly asking for more information about what kind of punishments he could face.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i2HcvXoesx4fPPH1Hm3pVTTLP6fw |title=AFP: Uganda rebel leader delays peace deal signing: top mediator |publisher=Afp.google.com |date=2008-04-10 |accessdate=2012-06-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612131244/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5i2HcvXoesx4fPPH1Hm3pVTTLP6fw |archive-date=2008-06-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> He later clarified that he wanted to know further details about how ''mato-oput'', the [[Acholi]] traditional justice, would be used, and how exactly the special division of the High Court would work;<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200804110001.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: Rebel Chief Refuses to Sign Peace Deal (Page 1 of 1)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> he then suspended the peace talks and appointed a new negotiating team, claiming to "have been misled".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article26715 |title=Ugandan rebels suspend peace talks, appoint new team |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> Specifically, Kony fired chief LRA negotiator David Nyakorach Matsanga and replaced him with James Obita.<ref name=NV21>[http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/632129 "Kony rebels attack SPLA camp, kill 21"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605143547/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/632129 |date=2011-06-05 }}, ''[[New Vision (newspaper)|The New Vision]]'', 6 June 2008</ref> Kony subsequently failed to show up at [[Nabanga]] to sign the treaty.<ref name=AFPenvoy>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5h39Frsg6D8NIKU_u_CDrMRcTigiQ "UN envoy tries to save Uganda peace talks"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610110903/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5h39Frsg6D8NIKU_u_CDrMRcTigiQ |date=2008-06-10 }}, ''AFP'' via Google, 8 June 2008</ref>
==Collapse== The government subsequently stated that they would return to Juba and Kampala, as the LRA had broken the agreement, and that the ceasefire agreement would not be extended. The next steps of both sides are unclear.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200804111165.html allAfrica.com: Uganda: Govt Suspends Indefinitely Signing Peace Deal With LRA (Page 1 of 2)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Diplomats unsuccessfully tried to restart the talks on 26 April 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article26792 |title=Diplomats prepare for more Ugandan peace talks |publisher=SudanTribune article |date= |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref> On 26 May 2008 the government set up a special war crimes court with the mandate to try the LRA in an attempt to convince the ICC to withdraw its indictments against LRA leaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7420461.stm |title=Africa | Uganda sets up war crimes court |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-05-26 |accessdate=2012-06-20}}</ref>
Since April 2008, the LRA had begun rearming and abducting recruits, with the ''BBC'' stating that 1000 new abductees had been added to the 600 old LRA fighters by June.<ref name=BBCprepare>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7440790.stm "Ugandan rebels 'prepare for war'"], BBC News, 6 June 2008</ref> Lord's Resistance Army negotiator James Obita stated that on 4 June 2008, the Southern Sudan army attacked an LRA encampment killing two, though this is unconfirmed.<ref name=AFP23>{{cite web|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5j-4WQfLeYuJLgI0XUAkHbOdC-jNQD915A0VO1 |title=23 people killed near Sudan-Congo border |publisher=''AFP'' via Google |date=8 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612134812/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5j-4WQfLeYuJLgI0XUAkHbOdC-jNQD915A0VO1 |archivedate=June 12, 2008 }}</ref> On 5 June 2008, the LRA attacked the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army/Movement]] (SPLA) camp at [[Nabanga]], killing 21, seven soldiers and 14 civilians, before killing a local chief in the nearby village of [[Yamba, Sudan|Yamba]].<ref name=AFPenvoy/> The LRA fighters burnt the SPLA camp before returning to [[Ri-Kwangba]].<ref name=NV21/> This occurred as Kony reappointed Matsanga as chief negotiator. Matsanga claimed on 6 June to have contacted UN Envoy Joaquim Chissano to revive the talks; Chissano subsequently arrived in Kampala for talks with President Museveni on 7 June.<ref name=AFPenvoy/> However, the Government of Southern Sudan announced on 8 June that they would no longer mediate, with Information Minister Gabriel Changson Cheng noting that there were multiple reasons for the decision, including the recent attack and the apparent lack of interest in the peace process on the part of the Ugandan government.<ref>[http://www.monitor.co.ug/artman/publish/sun_news/GoSS_suspends_talks_over_LRA_attack.shtml "GoSS suspends talks over LRA attack"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610051713/http://www.monitor.co.ug/artman/publish/sun_news/GoSS_suspends_talks_over_LRA_attack.shtml |date=2008-06-10 }}, ''[[The Monitor (Uganda)]]'', 8 June 2008</ref> The governments of the nations in which the LRA is active met earlier in the week and all suggested military action.<ref name=BBCprepare/>
In December 2008 the [[United Nations Security Council]] agreed with a Joaquim Chissano's recommendation that the peace efforts should continue will continuing to support the ICC arrest warrants.<ref>{{ UN document |docid=S-PV-6058 |body=Security Council |type=Verbatim Report |meeting=6058 |page=2 |anchor=pg002-bk07-pa03 |date=22 December 2008 |speakername=The President |accessdate=2008-12-31 }}</ref>

{{distinguish|tensor index notation}}
'''Abstract index notation''' is a mathematical notation for [[tensor]]s and [[spinor]]s that uses indices to indicate their types, rather than their components in a particular basis. The indices are mere placeholders, not related to any basis and, in particular, are non-numerical. Thus it should not be confused with the [[Ricci calculus]]. The notation was introduced by [[Roger Penrose]] as a way to use the formal aspects of the [[Einstein summation convention]] to compensate for the difficulty in describing [[tensor contraction|contraction]]s and [[covariant derivative|covariant differentiation]] in modern abstract tensor notation, while preserving the explicit [[Covariance and contravariance of vectors|covariance]] of the expressions involved.
Let ''V'' be a [[vector space]], and ''V''<sup>∗</sup> its [[dual space|dual]]. Consider, for example, an order-2 [[Covariance and contravariance of vectors|covariant]] tensor <math>h\in V^*\otimes V^*</math>. Then ''h'' can be identified with a [[bilinear form]] on ''V''. In other words, it is a function of two arguments in ''V'' which can be represented as a pair of ''slots'':
: <math>h = h(-,-).</math>
Abstract index notation is merely a ''labelling'' of the slots with Latin letters, which have no significance apart from their designation as labels of the slots (i.e., they are non-numerical):
: <math>h = h_{ab}.</math>
A [[tensor contraction]] (or trace) between two tensors is represented by the repetition of an index label, where one label is contravariant (an ''upper index'' corresponding to a tensor in ''V'') and one label is covariant (a ''lower index'' corresponding to a tensor in ''V''<sup>∗</sup>). Thus, for instance,
: <math>{t_{ab}}^b</math>
is the trace of a tensor ''t'' = ''t''<sub>ab</sub><sup>c</sup> over its last two slots. This manner of representing tensor contractions by repeated indices is formally similar to the [[Einstein summation convention]]. However, as the indices are non-numerical, it does not imply summation: rather it corresponds to the abstract basis-independent trace operation (or duality pairing) between tensor factors of type ''V'' and those of type ''V''<sup>∗</sup>.
== Abstract indices and tensor spaces ==
A general homogeneous tensor is an element of a [[tensor product]] of copies of ''V'' and ''V''<sup>∗</sup>, such as
:<math>V\otimes V^*\otimes V^* \otimes V\otimes V^*.</math>
Label each factor in this tensor product with a Latin letter in a raised position for each contravariant ''V'' factor, and in a lowered position for each covariant ''V''<sup>∗</sup> position. In this way, write the product as
:<math>V^a V_b V_c V^d V_e</math>
or, simply
:<math>{{{V^a}_{bc}}^d}_e.</math>
The last two expressions denote the same object as the first. Tensors of this type are denoted using similar notation, for example:
:<math>{{{h^a}_{bc}}^d}_e \in {{{V^a}_{bc}}^d}_e = V\otimes V^*\otimes V^* \otimes V\otimes V^*.</math>
==Contraction== {{See also|Tensor contraction}} In general, whenever one contravariant and one covariant factor occur in a tensor product of spaces, there is an associated ''contraction'' (or ''trace'') map. For instance,
:<math>\mathrm{Tr}_{12} : V\otimes V^*\otimes V^* \otimes V\otimes V^* \to V^* \otimes V\otimes V^*</math>
is the trace on the first two spaces of the tensor product.
:<math>\mathrm{Tr}_{15} : V\otimes V^*\otimes V^* \otimes V\otimes V^* \to V^* \otimes V^*\otimes V</math>
is the trace on the first and last space.
These trace operations are signified on tensors by the repetition of an index. Thus the first trace map is given by
:<math>\mathrm{Tr}_{12} : {{{h^a}_{bc}}^d}_e \mapsto {{{h^a}_{ac}}^d}_e</math>
and the second by
:<math>\mathrm{Tr}_{15} : {{{h^a}_{bc}}^d}_e \mapsto {{{h^a}_{bc}}^d}_a.</math>
==Braiding== To any tensor product on a single vector space, there are associated [[braided monoidal category|braiding maps]]. For example, the braiding map :<math> \tau_{(12)} : V\otimes V \rightarrow V\otimes V</math> interchanges the two tensor factors (so that its action on simple tensors is given by <math>\tau_{(12)} (v \otimes w) = w \otimes v</math>). In general, the braiding maps are in one-to-one correspondence with elements of the [[symmetric group]], acting by permuting the tensor factors. Here, we use <math>\tau_\sigma</math> to denote the braiding map associated to the permutation <math>\sigma</math> (represented as a product of disjoint [[cyclic permutation]]s).
Braiding maps are important in [[differential geometry]], for instance, in order to express the [[Bianchi identity]]. Here let <math>R</math> denote the Riemann tensor, regarded as a tensor in <math>V^* \otimes V^* \otimes V^* \otimes V</math>. The first Bianchi identity then asserts that :<math>R+\tau_{(123)}R+\tau_{(132)}R = 0.</math>
Abstract index notation handles braiding as follows. On a particular tensor product, an ordering of the abstract indices is fixed (usually this is a [[lexicographic order]]ing). The braid is then represented in notation by permuting the labels of the indices. Thus, for instance, with the Riemann tensor :<math>R={R_{abc}}^d\in {V_{abc}}^d = V^*\otimes V^*\otimes V^*\otimes V,</math> the Bianchi identity becomes :<math>{R_{abc}}^d+{R_{cab}}^d+{R_{bca}}^d = 0.</math>
== Antisymmetrization and Symmetrization == A general tensor may be antisymmetrized or symmetrized, and there is according notation.
We demonstrate the notation by example. Let's antisymmetrize the type-(0,3) tensor <math>\omega_{abc}</math>, where <math>\Sigma_3</math> is the symmetric group on three elements.
<math>\omega_{[abc]} := \frac{1}{3!} \sum_{\sigma \in \Sigma_3} (-1)^{\text{sgn}(\sigma)} \omega_{\sigma(a)\sigma(b)\sigma(c)}</math>
Similarly, we may symmetrize:
<math>\omega_{(abc)} := \frac{1}{3!} \sum_{\sigma \in \Sigma_3} \omega_{\sigma(a)\sigma(b)\sigma(c)}</math>
==See also== *[[Penrose graphical notation]] *[[Einstein notation]] *[[Index notation]] *[[Tensor]] *[[Antisymmetric tensor]] *[[Raising and lowering indices]] *[[Covariance and contravariance of vectors]]
==References== *[[Roger Penrose]], ''The Road to Reality: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe'', 2004, has a chapter explaining it. *[[Roger Penrose]] and [[Wolfgang Rindler]], ''Spinors and space-time'', volume I, ''two-spinor calculus and relativistic fields''.

{{Infobox scientist |name = Alexander Braun |image = Alexander Braun (1805-1877).png |caption = Alexander Braun |birth_date = 10 May 1805 |birth_place = Regensburg |death_date = {{death date and age|1877|3|29|1805|5|10|df=y}} |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = [[botany]] |work_institutions = [[University of Freiburg|Freiburg]]
[[University of Giessen|Giessen]]
[[University of Berlin]] |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[comparative anatomy|morphology]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Alexander Carl Heinrich Braun''' (10 May 1805 – 29 March 1877) was a German [[botanist]] from [[Regensburg]], Bavaria. His research centered on the morphology of plants. ==Biography== He studied botany in [[Heidelberg]], [[Paris]] and [[Munich]]. In 1833 he began teaching botany at the Polytechnic School of [[Karlsruhe]], staying there until 1846. Afterwards he was a professor of botany in [[University of Freiburg|Freiburg]] (from 1846), [[University of Giessen|Giessen]] (from 1850) and at the [[University of Berlin]] (1851), where he remained until 1877. While in Berlin, he was also director of the [[Berlin Botanical Garden|botanical garden]]. In 1852, he was elected a foreign member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]]. Braun is largely known for his research involving [[plant morphology]]. He accepted evolution but was a critic of [[Darwinism]].Glick, Thomas F. (1988). ''The Comparative Reception of Darwinism''. University of Chicago Press. p. 86. {{ISBN|0-226-29977-5}} He was a proponent of [[vitalism]], a popular 19th century speculative theory that claimed that a regulative force existed within living matter in order to maintain functionality. Despite these beliefs, Braun made important contributions in the field of [[cell theory]]. From his 1830s analysis of the arrangement of scales on a [[pine cone]] he was a pioneer of [[phyllotaxis]].[http://aob.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/80/3/231.pdf] A History of the Study of Phyllotaxis In 1877 [[Wilhelm Philippe Schimper]] and [[Philipp Bruch]] named the plant genus ''[[Braunia]]'' in his honor.[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=104560 EFloras, Flora of North America] Braunia Bruch & Schimper Also, a decorative plant known as "Braun's holly [[fern]]" (''[[Polystichum braunii]]'') commemorates his name.[https://books.google.com/books?id=UNe-JB5ftKEC&pg=PA326] Encyclopedia of garden ferns by Suzanne Olsen == Written works == * 1831: ''Untersuchung über die Ordnung der Schuppen an den Tannenzapfen'' (Investigation on the order of shapes in pine cones). * 1842: ''Nachträgliche Mitteilungen über die Gattungen Marsilia und Pilularia'' (Additional releases on the genera [[Marsilea]] and [[Pilularia]]). * 1850: ''Betrachtungen über die Erscheinung der Verjüngung in der Natur, insbesondere in der Lebens- und Bildungsgeschichte der Pflanze'' (Reflections on the phenomenon of rejuvenation in nature, particularly in the life and developmental history of the plant). * 1852: ''Über die Richtungsverhältnisse der Saftströme in den Zellen der Characeen''. (on directional conditions involving juice flow in the cell of [[Characeae]]). * 1853: ''Das Individuum der Pflanze in seinem Verhältnis zur Spezies etc.'' (The individual plant in its relation to species, etc.). * 1854: ''Über den schiefen Verlauf der Holzfaser und die dadurch bedingte Drehung der Stämme'' * 1854: ''Über einige neue und weniger bekannte Krankheiten der Pflanzen, welche durch Pilze erzeugt werden'' (On new and lesser-known diseases of plants produced by fungi). * 1854: ''Das Individuum der Species in seinem Verhältnis zur Pflanze'' (The individual of the species in its relationship to the plant). * 1855: "Algarum unicellularium genera nova et minus cognita". * 1856: ''Über Chytridium, eine Gattung einzelliger Schmarotzergewächse auf Algen und Infusorien'' (On [[Chytridiomycota|Chytridium]], a genus of unicellular parasites on [[algae]] and [[infusoria]]). * 1857: ''Über Parthenogenesis bei Pflanzen'' (On [[parthenogenesis]] in plants) * 1860: ''Über Polyembryonie und Keimung von Caelebogyne'' ([[Polyembryony]] and [[germination]] of [[Caelebogyne]]). * 1861: '' Index seminum Horti Botanici Berolinensis: Appendix Plantarum Novrum et minus cognitarum quea in Horto region botanico Berolinensi coluntur. * 1862: ''Über die Bedeutung der Morphologie'' (On the importance of morphology). * 1862: ''Zwei deutsche Isoetesarten'' (Two German [[Isoëtes]] species). * 1863: ''Über Isoetes'' (On [[quillwort]]s). * 1865: ''Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Gattung Selaginella'' (Contribution to the knowledge of the genus [[Selaginella]]). * 1867: ''Die Characeen Afrikas'' (African [[Characeae]]). * 1867: "Conspectus systematicus Characearum europaearum". * 1870: ''Neuere Untersuchungen über die Gattungen Marsilia und Pilularia'' (Recent studies on the genera [[Marsilea]] and [[Pilularia]]). * 1872: ''Über die Bedeutung der Entwicklung in der Naturgeschichte'' (On the importance of development in [[natural history]]). {{Botanist|A.Braun|Braun, Alexander}} == See also == * [[University of Freiburg Faculty of Biology]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * This article is based on a translation of the equivalent article at the [[German ''Rede bei der Enthüllung des Denkmals von Alexander Braun'', 1879 {{de-icon}} ==External links== * {{Cite NIE|wstitle=Braun, Alexander|year=1905 |short=x}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Braun, Alexander}} [[Category:1805 births]] [[Category:1877 deaths]] [[Category:German botanists]] [[Category:Non-Darwinian evolution]] [[Category:People from Regensburg]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Bavaria]] [[Category:Heidelberg University alumni]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich alumni]] [[Category:Humboldt University of Berlin faculty]] [[Category:University of Freiburg faculty]] [[Category:University of Giessen faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Members of the Bavarian Maximilian Order for Science and Art]] [[Category:Vitalists]]

In mathematics, '''BF algebras''' are a class of algebraic structures arising out of a symmetric "Yin Yang" concept for Bipolar Fuzzy logic, the name was introduced by Andrzej Walendziak in 2007. The name covers discrete versions, but a canonical example arises in the BF space [-1,0]x[0,1] of pairs of (false-ness, truth-ness).
==Definition== A '''BF-algebra''' is a non-empty [[subset]] <math>X</math> with a [[constant (mathematics)|constant]] <math>0</math> and a [[binary operation]] <math>*</math> satisfying the following: # <math>x*x=0</math> # <math>x*0=x</math> # <math>0*(x*y)=y*x</math>
== Example == Let <math>Z</math> be the [[Set_(mathematics)|set]] of [[integer]]s and '<math>-</math>' be the binary operation '[[subtraction]]'. Then the [[algebra]]ic structure <math>(Z,-)</math> obeys the following [[Property (philosophy)|properties]]: # <math>x-x=0</math> # <math>x-0=x</math> # <math>0-(x-y)=y-x</math>
==References==

{{Infobox | title = Carnism | titlestyle = background-color:#E5E4E2; | above-style = background-color: | image = [[File:Bummerandlazarus2.jpg|300px]] | caption = [[Emperor Norton|Joshua Norton]] eating meat, watched by [[street dog]]s [[Bummer and Lazarus]] in San Francisco in the 1860s. | headerstyle = background-color: | label2 = Description | data2 = Psychological theory about the ideology of animal use | label3 = Term coined by | data3 = [[Melanie Joy]], 2001 | label4 = Related ideas | data4 = [[Anthrozoology]], [[ethics of eating meat]], [[psychology of eating meat]], [[speciesism]], [[veganism]], [[vegetarianism]]
}} '''Carnism''' is a concept used in discussions of humanity's relation to other animals, defined as a prevailing [[ideology]] in which people support the use and consumption of [[animal product]]s, especially [[meat]].{{refn|group=n|Gibert, Martin; Desaulniers, Élise (2014):"Carnism refers to the ideology conditioning people to consume certain animal products. It is essentially the opposite of veganism."<ref name="Gibert2014" />}} Carnism is presented as a dominant belief system supported by a variety of [[defense mechanisms]] and mostly unchallenged assumptions.<ref name="Gibert2014" /><ref name=DeMello2012p138>{{cite book | title=Animals and Society: An Introduction to Human-Animal Studies | publisher=New York: Columbia University Press | author=DeMello, Margo | year=2012 | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=92Ct9iD1QTYC&pg=PA138 138]}}</ref><ref>Dhont, Kristof; Hodson, Gordon (2014). [https://kar.kent.ac.uk/41689/1/Dhont&Hodson%202014%20PAID.pdf "Why do right-wing adherents engage in more animal exploitation and meat consumption?"], ''Personality and Individual Differences'', 64, July (pp. 12–17), p. 4. {{doi|10.1016/j.paid.2014.02.002}}</ref><ref name=Kool2009pp353-356>Kool, V. K.; Agrawal, Rita (2009). "The Psychology of Nonkilling", in Joám Evans Pim (ed.),''Toward a Nonkilling Paradigm'', [[Center for Global Nonkilling]], pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=TzDZYc8SGigC&pg=PA353 353–356].</ref> The term ''carnism'' was coined by social psychologist and author [[Melanie Joy]] in 2001 and popularized by her book ''[[Why We Love Dogs, Eat Pigs, and Wear Cows]]'' (2009).<ref name="Joy2011p9">[[Melanie Joy|Joy, Melanie]] (2011) [2009]. ''Why We Love Dogs, Eat Pigs, and Wear Cows: An Introduction to Carnism''. Conari Press, p. 9. {{ISBN|1573245054}}.</ref><ref>Rose, Marla (8 November 2010). [http://advocacy.britannica.com/blog/advocacy/2010/11/interview-dr-melanie-joy-on-why-we-love-dogs-eat-pigs-and-wear-cows/ "An Interview with Dr. Melanie Joy"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' Advocacy for Animals.</ref><ref>[[Ben Schott|Schott, Ben]] (11 January 2010). [http://schott.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/11/carnism/ "Carnism"], Schott's Vocab, ''The New York Times''.</ref>
Central to the ideology, according to the theory, is the acceptance of meat-eating as "natural", "normal", "necessary", and (sometimes) "nice".{{refn|group=n|Joy introduced the "Three Ns of Justification", namely that meat-eating is regarded as "normal, natural, and necessary".<ref name=Joy2011p96>Joy 2011, p. 96.</ref> A 2015 paper developed this into the "Four Ns": "natural, normal, necessary, and nice".<ref name="Piazza2015" /><ref name="Singal4June2015">Singal, Jesse (4 June 2015). [http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2015/06/4-ways-people-rationalize-eating-meat.html "The 4 Ways People Rationalize Eating Meat"], ''New York Magazine''.</ref>}} An important feature of carnism is the classification of only particular species of animal as food, and the acceptance of practices toward those animals that would be rejected as unacceptable [[Cruelty to animals|cruelty]] if applied to other species. This classification is culturally relative, so that, for example, dogs are eaten by some people in Korea but may be pets in the West, while cows are eaten in the West but [[Cattle in religion|protected]] in much of India.<ref name="Gibert2014" />
==History== {{see also|Ethics of eating meat|History of vegetarianism}}
Analyzing the history of vegetarianism and opposition to it from ancient Greece to the present day, literary scholar Renan Larue found certain commonalities in what he described as carnist arguments. According to him, carnists typically held that vegetarianism is a ludicrous idea unworthy of attention, that mankind is invested with dominion over animals by divine authority, and that abstaining from violence against animals would pose a threat to humans. He found that the views that farmed animals do not suffer, and that slaughter is preferable to death by disease or predation, gained currency in the nineteenth century, but that the former had precedent in the writings of [[Porphyry (philosopher)|Porphyry]], a vegetarian who advocated the humane production of animal products which do not require animals to be slaughtered, such as wool.<ref name="Desaulniers30Jan2015">{{cite web | url=http://penseravantdouvrirlabouche.com/2015/01/30/le-vegetarisme-et-ses-ennemis-entrevue-avec-renan-larue/ | title=Le végétarisme et ses ennemis: entrevue avec Renan Larue | date=30 January 2015 | accessdate=6 August 2015 | author=[[Élise Desaulniers|Desaulniers, Élise]]}}</ref>
In the 1970s traditional views on the moral standing of animals were challenged by [[animal rights]] advocates, including psychologist [[Richard D. Ryder|Richard Ryder]], who in 1971 introduced the notion of [[speciesism]]. This is defined as the assignment of value and rights to individuals solely on the basis of their [[species]] membership.<ref>[[Richard D. Ryder|Ryder, Richard D.]] (1971). "Experiments on Animals", in Stanley Godlovitch, Roslind Godlovitch, John Harris (eds.), ''Animals, Men and Morals'', Grove Press.{{parabr}}Ryder, Richard D. (2009). "Speciesism", in [[Marc Bekoff]] (ed.), ''Encyclopedia of Animal Rights and Animal Welfare'', Greenwood; [[Cora Diamond|Diamond, Cora]] (2004). "Eating Meat and Eating People", in [[Cass Sunstein]], [[Martha Nussbaum]] (eds.), ''Animal Rights: Current Debates and New Directions'', Oxford University Press, p. 93.</ref> In 2001 psychologist and animal rights advocate Melanie Joy coined the term ''carnism'' for a form of speciesism that she argues underpins using animals for food, and particularly killing them for meat.<ref name=Joy2001>[[Melanie Joy|Joy, Melanie]] (2001). [http://www.satyamag.com/sept01/joy.html "From Carnivore to Carnist: Liberating the Language of Meat"], ''Satya'', 18(2), September, pp. 126–127; Joy, Melanie (2003). ''Psychic Numbing and Meat Consumption: The Psychology of Carnism'', doctoral dissertion, Saybrook Graduate School, San Francisco.</ref> Joy compares carnism to [[patriarchy]], arguing that both are dominant normative ideologies that go unrecognized because of their ubiquity:<ref name="Gibert2014">{{cite book | url=https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-94-007-0929-4_83 | title=Encyclopedia of Food and Agricultural Ethics | chapter = Carnism | chapterurl=https://martingibert.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/gibert-desaulniers-2013-carnism.pdf| publisher=Springer Netherlands | author=Gibert, Martin; [[Élise Desaulniers|Desaulniers, Élise]]| year=2014 | pages=292–298 | isbn=978-94-007-0929-4}}</ref><!--ref name="Braunsberger2015">{{cite book | chapterurl=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-10873-5_201 | title=The Sustainable Global Marketplace | publisher=Springer International Publishing |author1=Braunsberger, Karin |author2=Flamm, Richard O. | year=2015 | pages=345 | isbn=978-3-319-10873-5 | chapter=Consumer Identities: Carnism Versus Veganism}}</ref><ref name="Webster1994">{{cite conference | first = A. J. F. | last =Webster | title =Meat and right: The ethical dilemma | booktitle =Proceedings of the Nutrition Society|volume=54| pages = 263–270 | year=1994 |url=http://www.researchgate.net/profile/A_Webster/publication/15227380_Meat_and_right_the_ethical_dilemma/links/00b495346972e71c91000000.pdf | doi =10.1079/PNS19940031}}.</ref>--><!--[[Abolitionism (animal rights)|Abolitionist]] [[Gary Francione]] argues against this that carnism is not a hidden ideology, but a conscious choice; in his view some animals are viewed as food and others family because humans regard non-humans as property, and they may value that property as they please.<ref>{{cite web|author=Francione, Gary L.|date=1 October 2012|url=http://www.abolitionistapproach.com/carnism-there-is-nothing-invisible-about-the-ideology-of-animal-exploitation/#.VaRgmjg3RGk|title='Carnism'? There is nothing 'invisible' about the ideology of animal exploitation|publisher=abolitionistapproach.com}}</ref>-->
{{quote|We don't see meat eating as we do vegetarianism – as a choice, based on a set of assumptions about animals, our world, and ourselves. Rather, we see it as a given, the "natural" thing to do, the way things have always been and the way things will always be. We eat animals without thinking about what we are doing and why, because the belief system that underlies this behavior is invisible. This invisible belief system is what I call ''carnism''.<ref name="Joy2011p9" />}}
Sandra Mahlke argues that carnism is the "central crux of speciesism" because the eating of meat motivates ideological justification for other forms of animal exploitation.<ref name="Mahle2014">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F6hPAwAAQBAJ | title=Das Machtverhältnis zwischen Mensch und Tier im Kontext sprachlicher Distanzierungsmechanismen: Anthropozentrismus, Speziesismus und Karnismus in der kritischen Diskursanalyse | publisher=Diplomica Verlag | author=Mahlke, Sandra | year=2014 | isbn=978-3-8428-9140-1}}</ref>
==Features== ===Edible or inedible=== {{multiple image|caption_align=center | align = right | header = Examples of cultural differences | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = Surabhi Cow Vrindavan.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = A cow rests in the street in [[Vrindavan]]. In some Eastern cultures, cows are [[Cattle in religion|revered]], whereas in some Western cultures they are eaten as [[beef]]. | image2 = Dog on a stick.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = Cooked dog and poultry in China. In some Western cultures, dogs are not eaten as meat but poultry is, whereas in some Eastern cultures dogs are eaten as [[dog meat|dog-meat]]. }} A central aspect of carnism is that animals are categorized as edible, inedible, pets, [[vermin]], predators, or entertainment animals, according to people's [[Schema (psychology)|schemata]] – mental classifications that determine, and are determined by, our beliefs and desires.<ref name="Gibert2014" /><ref name="Joy2011pp14,17" /> There is cultural variability regarding which animals count as food. Dogs are eaten in China, and South Korea, but elsewhere are not viewed as food, either because they are loved or, as in the Middle East and parts of India, regarded as unclean.<ref name="Gibert2014" /><!-- <ref name="Podberscek2009" /> --><ref>Herzog, Hal (2011). [https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/animals-and-us/201106/having-your-dog-and-eating-it-too "Having Your Dog and Eating It Too?"], ''Psychology Today''.</ref> Cows are eaten in the West, but revered in much of India. Pigs are rejected by Muslims and Jews but widely regarded by other groups as edible.<ref name="Winzeler2012">{{cite book|author=Robert L. Winzeler|title=Anthropology and Religion: What We Know, Think, and Question|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mREqLR4uqp8C&pg=PA63|date=12 April 2012|publisher=AltaMira Press|isbn=978-0-7591-2191-1|pages=63}}</ref><!-- LAVIN SOURCE UNDEFINED: <ref>Lavin 2013, pp. 116–117.</ref>--> Joy and other psychologists argue that these taxonomies determine how the animals within them are treated, influence subjective perceptions of their sentience and intelligence, and reduce or increase [[empathy]] and moral concern for them.<ref name=Joy2011pp14,17>Joy 2011, pp. 14, 17.</ref>
===Meat paradox=== {{main|Psychology of eating meat#Meat paradox}} Jeff Mannes writes that carnism is rooted in a paradox between most people's values and actions: they oppose harming animals, and yet eat them. He argues that this conflict leads to [[cognitive dissonance]], which people attempt to attenuate through [[psychic numbing]].<ref name="Mannes2015">{{cite book | url=http://www.transcript-verlag.de/978-3-8376-2232-4/lexikon-der-mensch-tier-beziehungen | title=Lexikon der Mensch-Tier-Beziehungen | chapter = Karnismus | publisher=Transcript Verlag | author=Mannes, Jeff| year=2015 | pages=191–193 | isbn=978-3-8376-2232-4}}</ref> The apparent conflict between caring about animals and embracing diets which require them to be harmed has been termed the "[[Psychology of eating meat#Meat paradox|meat paradox]]".<ref name=Loughnan2014>Loughnan, Steve; Bastian, Brock; Haslam, Nick (2014). [https://foodethics.univie.ac.at/fileadmin/user_upload/inst_ethik_wiss_dialog/Loughnan__S._2014_And_Bastian._..The_Psychology_of_Eating_Animals._In._CURRENT_DIRECTIONS_IN_PSYCHOLOGICAL_SCIENCE.pdf "The Psychology of Eating Animals"], ''Current Directions in Psychological Science'', 23(2), April, pp. 104–108. {{doi|10.1177/0963721414525781}}</ref><ref name="Loughnan2010">{{cite journal | title=The role of meat consumption in the denial of moral status and mind to meat animals | author=Loughnan, Steve| journal=Appetite |year=2010 | volume=55 | issue=1 | pages=156–159 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2010.05.043 | pmid=20488214|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name=Fawcett2013p215>Fawcett, Anne (2013). "Euthanasia and morally justifiable killing in a veterinary clinical context", in Jay Johnston, Fiona Probyn-Rapsey (eds.), ''Animal Death'', Sydney: Sydney University Press, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=BaGUOm2SRngC&pg=PA215 215].</ref>
There is experimental evidence supporting the idea that the meat paradox induces cognitive dissonance in Westerners.<ref name="Piazza2015" /><ref name="Rothgerber2014">{{cite journal | title=Efforts to overcome vegetarian-induced dissonance among meat eaters | author=Rothgerber, Hank | journal=Appetite |date=August 2014 | volume=79 | pages=32–41 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2014.04.003}}</ref><ref>Hodson, Gordon (3 March 2014). [https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/without-prejudice/201403/the-meat-paradox-loving-exploiting-animals "The Meat Paradox: Loving but Exploiting Animals"], ''Psychology Today''.</ref> Westerners are more willing to eat animals which they regard as having lesser mental capacities and moral standing, and conversely, to attribute lesser mental faculties and moral standing to animals which are eaten.<ref name="Loughnan2014" /><ref name="Bastian2011">{{cite journal | url=https://www2.psy.uq.edu.au/~uqbbast1/Bastian%20et%20al%20PSPB%20in%20press.pdf|doi=10.1177/0146167211424291 | title=Don’t mind meat? The denial of mind to animals used for human consumption | author=Bastian, Brock| journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin |date=2011 | volume=38 | issue=2 | pages=247–256|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Furthermore, the relationship is causative: the categorization of animals as food or not affects people's perception of their mental characteristics, and the act of eating meat itself causes people to attribute diminished mental capacity to animals.<ref name="Loughnan2014" /> For example, in one study people rated an unfamiliar exotic animal as less intelligent if they were told native people hunted it, and in another they regarded cows as less intelligent after eating beef jerky.<ref name="Loughnan2014" />
Avoiding consideration of the provenance of [[animal product]]s is another strategy.<ref name=Plous2002>{{cite book|last1=Plous|first1=Scott|editor1-last=Plous|editor1-first=Scott|title=Understanding Prejudice and Discrimination|date=2002|publisher=McGraw Hill Higher Education|isbn=0-07-255443-6|pages=509–528|url=http://www.understandingprejudice.org/pdf/animals.pdf?logged=true|accessdate=9 August 2015|chapter=Is there such a thing as discrimination towards animals?}}</ref> Joy argues that this is why meat is rarely served with the animal's head or other intact body parts.<ref>Joy 2011, p. 16.</ref>
{{anchor|4 Ns}}<!-- Linked to by [[Psychology of eating meat]]. This should appear directly before the section currently titled "Justification" which discusses the 4 N's"-->
===Justification=== Joy introduced the idea of the "Three Ns of Justification", writing that meat-eaters regard [[meat consumption]] as "normal, natural, and necessary".<ref name="Joy2011p96" /><ref name="Singal4June2015" /> She argues that the "Three Ns" have been invoked to justify other ideologies, including slavery and denying women the right to vote, and are widely recognized as problematic only after the ideology they support has been dismantled.<ref>Joy 2011, p. 97.</ref>
The argument holds that people are conditioned to believe that humans evolved to eat meat, that it is expected of them, and that they need it to survive or be strong. These beliefs are said to be reinforced by various institutions, including religion, family and the media. Although scientists have shown that humans get more than enough protein in their diets without eating meat,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://nutritionfacts.org/video/do-vegetarians-get-enough-protein/ | title = Do vegetarians get enough protein? | first1 = Michael | last1 = Greger | date = 6 June 2014}}</ref> the belief that meat is required persists.<ref name="Piazza2015" /><ref name="Singal4June2015" />
Building on Joy's work, psychologists conducted a series of studies in the United States and Australia, published in 2015, that found the great majority of meat-eaters' stated justifications for consuming meat were based on the "Four Ns" – "natural, normal, necessary, and nice". The arguments were that humans are [[omnivore]]s (''natural''), that most people eat meat (''normal''), that vegetarian diets are lacking in nutrients (''necessary''), and that meat tastes good (''nice'').<ref name="Piazza2015">{{cite journal | title=Rationalizing meat consumption. The 4Ns | author=Piazza, Jared| journal=Appetite |date=August 2015 | volume=91 | pages=114–128 | doi=10.1016/j.appet.2015.04.011|display-authors=etal | pmid=25865663}}{{paragraph break}} [http://www.lancaster.ac.uk/news/articles/2015/how-people-defend-eating-meat/ "How people defend eating meat"], Lancaster University, 15 May 2015.</ref><ref name="Singal4June2015" /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/diet-and-fitness/meat-eaters-justify-diet-using-four-ns-natural-necessary-normal-nice-20150531-ghd5le.html | title=Meat eaters justify diet using 'Four Ns': natural, necessary, normal, nice | date=1 June 2015 | author=Goodyer, Paula |work = Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
Meat-eaters who endorsed these arguments more strongly reported less guilt about their dietary habits. They tended to objectify animals, have less moral concern for them and attribute less consciousness to them. They were also more supportive of [[social inequality]] and hierarchical ideologies, and less proud of their consumer choices.<ref name="Piazza2015" />
==="Saved from slaughter" narratives=== [[File:Obama ThanksGiving Turkey Pardon 2009.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|The [[National Thanksgiving Turkey Presentation]], in which the American president pardons a turkey, has been cited as an illustration of carnism.<ref name="Freeman2012p103" />]]
An illustration of dissonance reduction is the prominence given to "saved from slaughter" stories, in which the media focus on one animal that evaded slaughter, while ignoring the millions that did not.<ref name="Mizelle2015p264" /> Joy wrote that this dichotomy is characteristic of carnism.<ref>Joy 2011, pp. 135,150</ref>
Animals at the center of these narratives include Wilbur in ''[[Charlotte's Web]]'' (1952); the eponymous and fictional star of ''[[Babe (film)|Babe]]'' (1995); Christopher Hogwood in [[Sy Montgomery]]'s ''The Good, Good Pig'' (2006);<ref name=Mizelle2015p264>Mizelle, Brett (2015). "Unthinkable Visibility: Pigs, Pork and the Spectacle of Killing and Meat", in Marguerite S. Shaffer, Phoebe S. K. Young (eds.), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=AXoJCgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Rendering Nature: Animals, Bodies, Places, Politics]'', University of Pennsylvania Press, p. 264; Mizelle, Brett (2012). ''Pig'', Reaktion Books, pp. 105–106.</ref> the [[Tamworth Two]]; and [[Cincinnati Freedom]]. The American [[National Thanksgiving Turkey Presentation]] is cited as another example. A 2012 study found that most media reporting on it celebrated the [[Poultry farming|poultry industry]] while marginalizing the link between living animals and meat.<ref name=Freeman2012p103>Packwood-Freeman, Carrie; Perez, Oana Leventi (2012). "Pardon Your Turkey and Eat Him Too", in Joshua Frye, Michael S. Bruner (eds.), ''The Rhetoric of Food: Discourse, Materiality, and Power'', Routledge, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=IR9woMrfFs4C&pg=PA103 103ff].</ref>
==Non-academic reception== Opinion pieces in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', ''[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]'', and ''[[The Drum (TV program)|The Drum]]'' praised the idea, saying the term made it easier to discuss, and challenge, the practices of animal exploitation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Stephan|title=Friend or Food? The Ideology of How We Decide|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/stephan-spencer/carnism_b_1876600.html|website=The Huffington Post: The Blog|date=13 Sep 2013|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gandhi|first1=Maneka|title=From cuisine to corpses to ‘carnism’|url=http://www.thestatesman.com/mobi/news/8th-day/from-cuisine-to-corpses-to-carnism/73696.html|publisher=The Statesman|date=5 Jul 2015|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Fox|first1=Katrina|title=Eating meat isn't natural: it's carnism|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-06-18/35008|website=The Drum|publisher=ABC|date=28 Sep 2010|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref> An article in the beef industry publication Drovers Cattle Network criticized the use of the term, saying it implied that eating animal foods was a "psychological sickness".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murphy|first1=Dan|title=Commentary: The carnist conundrum|url=http://www.cattlenetwork.com/cattle-news/Commentary-The-carnist-conundrum-128069853.html|publisher=Drovers Cattle Network|accessdate=19 August 2015|date=19 Aug 2011}}</ref>
